newsitem.title: CHINA: CLAMOUR FOR STOCKS IN BEIJING AFTER DEPOSIT CUT.
newsitem.headline: CLAMOUR FOR STOCKS IN BEIJING AFTER DEPOSIT CUT.

text.p: More people in Beijing have shown an interest in investing in stocks after exchanges recently cut the deposit requirement to open an account, the Financial News said on Tuesday.
Stock trading accounts opened by residents in China's capital were expected to reach 1.1 million by the end of this year, the newspaper said.
About 2,064 accounts were opened by individuals every day from August 4 to 8, up 78.0 percent compared with the daily average in July, it said.
Many stock trading centres in Beijing opened telephone trading and sharply cut deposits this month to attract more investors, the newspaper said.
In some centres, investors need to pay only 200 yuan ($25) in commission to open a telephone trading account. Previously the deposit to open an account was at least 50,000 yuan, it said.
More individual businessmen and laid-off workers were among those opening accounts, it added.
